[What is the main point?]: The main point is that the Defense Science Board (DSB) projected $6 billion annual savings for CONUS logistics through outsourcing, but this estimate is likely overstated due to various factors and legal barriers.
[Why is it happening?]: The Department of Defense (DOD) aims to increase investments in modernization without increasing overall defense budgets, and seeks to reduce support operations costs to allocate more funds for modernization and other defense priorities.
[Who is involved?]: The Defense Science Board (DSB), the Office of the Secretary of Defense (OSD), the Program Analysis and Evaluation (PA&E) directorate, the Center for Naval Analyses (CNA), and the Logistics Management Institute (LMI) are involved in assessing and analyzing the potential savings from outsourcing support services.
[When is the action happening?]: The action is ongoing, with the DSB issuing reports in 1996 and the PA&E directorate assessing the DSB's findings for the Quadrennial Defense Review (QDR).
[Where is the action happening?]: The action is happening within the DOD, with various locations including the Logistics Management Institute in Arlington, Virginia, the Office of Maintenance Policy, the Office of Program Analysis and Evaluation, and the Defense Science Board in Washington, D.C.

[What is the main point?]: The main point is to examine the actions taken by federal agencies to maintain performance amid workforce reductions between fiscal years 1993 and 1996, focusing on specific components within HUD, DOI, GSA, NASA, and OPM.
[Why is it happening?]: The reductions were part of a federal effort to cut costs and control deficits, driven by the Federal Workforce Restructuring Act of 1994 and the National Performance Review.
[Who is involved?]: The federal government, Congress, the administration, various federal agencies (HUD, DOI, GSA, NASA, and OPM), their components, unions, employee associations, and customers.
[When is the action happening?]: The workforce reductions and performance maintenance actions were examined between fiscal years 1993 and 1996.
[Where is the action happening?]: The actions were taking place at the headquarters of the parent agencies and components in Washington, D.C., at the KSC in Florida, and at BOR’s Reclamation Service Center in Denver, CO.

[What is the main point?]: The IRS's National Research Program (NRP) aims to obtain new information about taxpayers' compliance with tax laws, focusing on accurate voluntary reporting compliance data while minimizing the burden on taxpayers.

[Why is it happening?]: The IRS needs to measure overall compliance, develop formulas to select likely noncompliant returns for audit, and identify compliance problems to address.

[Who is involved?]: The IRS, taxpayers with returns in the NRP sample, and third parties such as employers and banks.

[When is the action happening?]: The IRS conducted tests and implemented NRP from September 2002 through April 2003, with ongoing efforts to assess and improve NRP implementation.

[Where is the action happening?]: The actions are taking place at IRS area offices in various locations, including Baltimore, Maryland; Brooklyn, New York; Oakland, California; Philadelphia, Pennsylvania; and St. Paul, Minnesota.

[What is the main point?]: The main point is that thorough and comprehensive planning is essential for the cost-effectiveness and success of the decennial census, as evidenced by past experiences where poor planning led to increased costs and risks.

[Why is it happening?]: It is happening because the Bureau of the Census is planning the 2010 Census and aims to avoid the mistakes of the 2000 Census by implementing a more rigorous planning process, which includes developing a comprehensive project plan, improving budgetary transparency, and conducting thorough risk assessments.

[Who is involved?]: The Bureau of the Census, the Office of Management and Budget (OMB), the National Academy of Sciences (NAS), and various advisory committees are involved in the planning and oversight of the 2010 Census.

[When is the action happening?]: The planning and review process for the 2010 Census is ongoing, with the Bureau having established an executive steering committee and various research and development planning groups. The Bureau's life cycle cost estimates are expected to be updated early in the calendar year 2004.

[Where is the action happening?]: The actions are happening within the Bureau's Decennial Management Division, which is responsible for planning the 2010 Census, including the American Community Survey (ACS) and the Master Address File/Topologically Integrated Geographic Encoding and Referencing (MAF/TIGER) enhancements. The Bureau's planning activities are also subject to review and oversight by the OMB and NAS.

[What is the main point?]: The main point is that the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) has established a framework to protect the privacy and security of Medicare beneficiaries' protected health information (PHI) when used for purposes other than direct clinical care, but there are gaps in guidance and periodic audits for compliance.

[Why is it happening?]: It is happening due to the need to ensure that covered entities and business associates are complying with HIPAA regulations, including properly de-identifying PHI when used for non-clinical purposes.

[Who is involved?]: The Department of Health and Human Services (HHS), Office for Civil Rights (OCR), covered entities, business associates, and Medicare beneficiaries are involved in this process.

[When is the action happening?]: The actions are ongoing, with HHS having established a framework for protecting PHI and OCR conducting enforcement and compliance activities.

[Where is the action happening?]: The actions are happening within the Department of Health and Human Services in Washington, D.C., and through OCR's enforcement and compliance activities.

[What is the main point?]: The main point is that the Military Health System (MHSS) has no current or upcoming need for clinical psychologists who may prescribe medication, and the costs of training such psychologists are substantial.

[Why is it happening?]: The MHSS implemented the Prescribing Psychologist Development Program (PDP) to train clinical psychologists to prescribe psychotropic medication, but due to persistent implementation issues, lack of clear benefits, and sufficient existing psychiatrists, there is no justification for continuing the program.

[Who is involved?]: The MHSS, the Department of Defense (DOD), the American Psychiatric Association, the American Psychological Association, and Vector Research, Inc. (VRI) are involved in the evaluation and implementation of the PDP.

[When is the action happening?]: The PDP was implemented between 1991 and 1998, with the last class completing training in 1998.

[Where is the action happening?]: The actions related to the PDP are happening within the MHSS and DOD, specifically at military medical facilities and the Uniformed Services University for the Health Sciences (USUHS).

[What is the main point?] The James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) project is facing significant technical challenges and cost overruns, with the cryocooler being a major issue, potentially impacting the project's ability to meet its schedule and cost commitments.

[Why is it happening?] The project has experienced delays and increased costs due to technical challenges, particularly with the cryocooler, and contractor performance issues. The complexity of the project, which incorporates nine critical technologies and 15 pre-existing technologies, has led to unforeseen risks and technical challenges during integration and testing.

[Who is involved?] The JWST project involves NASA, Northrop Grumman, Harris Corporation, the Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL), and the Space Telescope Science Institute (STScI). Northrop Grumman is the prime contractor responsible for developing the sunshield, Optical Telescope Element (OTE), spacecraft, and a cooling subsystem for the Mid-Infrared Instrument (MIRI). Harris is manufacturing test equipment and assisting in testing, while STScI is managing research proposals and storing scientific data.

[When is the action happening?] The project has been ongoing for almost 7 years, with the third major integration and test period starting in 2016. The project is currently on schedule with 8.75 months of schedule reserve remaining, but all elements and major subsystems are nearing the critical path, potentially reducing the schedule reserve further.

[Where is the action happening?] The actions are taking place at various NASA centers, including Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Maryland, the Independent Verification & Validation facility in Fairmont, West Virginia, and at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, California. The Space Telescope Science Institute is also involved, located in Baltimore, Maryland.

[What is the main point?]: The main point is that the U.S. government, specifically DHS and EPA, recognize the need for federal legislation to effectively regulate chemical facility security due to the significant risks posed by these facilities and the lack of current authority to ensure their preparedness against terrorist attacks.

[Why is it happening?]: It is happening because chemical facilities are considered attractive targets for terrorists, and there is a need for comprehensive security assessments and measures that are currently not mandated by federal law.

[Who is involved?]: The Department of Homeland Security (DHS), the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), industry associations, and various stakeholders including chemical manufacturers, research centers, and government representatives are involved in discussions and efforts to improve chemical facility security.

[When is the action happening?]: The action is ongoing, with DHS and EPA calling for legislation since 2002, and various bills introduced in the 109th Congress, none of which have been acted upon yet.

[Where is the action happening?]: The action is happening at chemical facilities across the United States, with DHS and EPA working on plans and programs to enhance security, and industry associations promoting voluntary security measures among their members.

[What is the main point?]: The main point is that federal agencies, particularly DHS, face ongoing challenges in ensuring that privacy concerns are addressed early, reassessed with key programmatic changes, and thoroughly reflected in guidance on emerging technologies and uses of personal data.

[Why is it happening?]: This is happening due to the increasing use of technologies like data mining, RFID, and information resellers, which raise privacy concerns, and the need for consistent privacy protections across various programs and applications.

[Who is involved?]: The main entities involved are federal agencies, particularly DHS, and information resellers. Other entities include the Office of the Director of National Intelligence, the DHS Privacy Office, and the public.

[When is the action happening?]: The action is ongoing, with past instances of privacy concerns being identified and recommendations made to address them.

[Where is the action happening?]: The action is happening within the context of federal agencies' programs and systems, as well as the emerging information sharing environment.

[What is the main point?] The main point is that Social Security, a significant federal program in the U.S., provides benefits to over 49 million beneficiaries, including retirees, disabled workers, and dependents, and is facing financial challenges that may necessitate benefit reductions or other reforms to ensure its long-term solvency.

[Why is it happening?] The Social Security program is facing solvency issues due to demographic changes, such as the retirement of the baby boomer generation, increased life expectancy, and decreased fertility rates, which have resulted in a situation where the program has collected more in taxes than it has paid out in benefits, but this is expected to reverse in the near future.

[Who is involved?] The Social Security Administration, the Department of the Treasury, and various stakeholders, including disabled workers, dependents, retirees, and policymakers, are involved in addressing the program's financial challenges and potential reforms.

[When is the action happening?] The action is ongoing, with discussions and proposals for reform continuing to address the program's solvency concerns.

[Where is the action happening?] The action is happening within the U.S. federal government, specifically in Washington, D.C., where the Social Security Administration and the Department of the Treasury are based.

[What is the main point?]: The main point is to examine the condition and status of nonhousing-related Troubled Asset Relief Programs (TARP) and TARP-funded housing programs, assessing their utilization, assets held, obligations, disbursements, income, and exit considerations.

[Why is it happening?]: This examination is happening to understand the impact and effectiveness of the TARP programs, especially in light of the financial crisis that began in 2008, and to inform decisions on the continuation or wind-down of these programs.

[Who is involved?]: The U.S. Department of the Treasury, the Office of Financial Stability (OFS), various financial institutions, and the government are involved in the implementation and oversight of the TARP programs.

[When is the action happening?]: The action of examining the TARP programs is ongoing, with the performance audit conducted from September 2014 to January 2015.

[Where is the action happening?]: The action is happening in the context of the U.S. financial system, particularly in relation to the aftermath of the 2008 financial crisis and the implementation of the Emergency Economic Stabilization Act (EESA) and its associated TARP programs.

[What is the main point?]: The main point is that the electricity sector in the United States is undergoing a significant transition due to new environmental regulations and market changes, leading to the retirement of coal-fueled generating units and the implementation of retrofits to reduce emissions.

[Why is it happening?]: This transition is happening due to the abundance of coal and its historically low cost, but concerns over air pollution, water resources, and solid waste have led to the enactment of environmental laws and regulations. The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has proposed or finalized four key regulations affecting coal-fueled units, and a new regulation to reduce carbon dioxide emissions from existing generating units is also being considered.

[Who is involved?]: The main stakeholders involved are the Department of Energy (DOE), the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC), regional transmission organizations (RTOs), state environmental and electricity regulators, and system planners.

[When is the action happening?]: The actions are ongoing, with initial steps taken since a July 2012 report. The EPA's Mercury and Air Toxics Standards (MATS) regulation has taken effect, and the proposed regulations to reduce carbon dioxide emissions are expected to be finalized and implemented by 2030.

[Where is the action happening?]: The actions are happening across the United States, with a focus on regions with a large amount of capacity that must comply with the MATS regulation, such as the PJM Interconnection, Midcontinent ISO, Southwest Power Pool, and the Electric Reliability Council of Texas.

[What is the main point?]: The main point is that the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has been facing challenges with its ATC system modernization program, including cost overruns, schedule delays, and performance shortfalls.
[Why is it happening?]: The challenges are due to various factors such as lack of a complete systems architecture, unreliable cost information, unmature software acquisition processes, and an organizational culture that does not always act in the agency's long-term best interest.
[Who is involved?]: The FAA, Congress, and the aviation community are involved in addressing these challenges.
[When is the action happening?]: The FAA has been working on modernization projects over the past 16 years, with ongoing efforts and plans to continue through fiscal year 2003.
[Where is the action happening?]: The actions are taking place at FAA's facilities, including en route centers, terminal radar approach control facilities, and other major FAA facilities across the United States.

[What is the main point?]: The main point is that from 1993 to 1998, the United States increased its rule of law funding globally, with a notable shift in funding from Latin America and the Caribbean to Central Europe.

[Why is it happening?]: The increase in funding may be due to the expansion of U.S. rule of law programs and related activities worldwide, while the decline in Latin America and the Caribbean could be attributed to issues with USAID's information system in 1996.

[Who is involved?]: The United States, through USAID, is the primary entity involved in funding rule of law programs and activities.

[When is the action happening?]: The action is happening over the fiscal years 1993-98.

[Where is the action happening?]: The funding is happening worldwide, with a significant portion going to Latin America and the Caribbean, Central Europe, Africa, and the newly independent states of the former Soviet Union.

[What is the main point?] The main point is that franchise funds, which are government-run enterprises managed by federal employees, are not always adhering to competitive procedures and other sound contracting practices when providing contracting services to the Department of Defense (DOD), potentially leading to increased costs and suboptimal outcomes for the government.

[Why is it happening?] This is happening due to a lack of adherence to federal procurement regulations, unclear roles and responsibilities among the parties involved, and the incentive to prioritize customer service and convenience over compliance with contracting policy and procedures.

[Who is involved?] The involved parties include the Department of Defense (DOD), the franchise funds managed by the departments of the Interior and the Treasury (GovWorks and FedSource), and the contractors providing goods and services.

[When is the action happening?] The action of using franchise funds for contracting services is ongoing, with the review conducted between June 2004 and June 2005.

[Where is the action happening?] The action is happening within the context of the franchise funds' operations, specifically in the areas of contracting services provided to DOD customers.

[What is the main point?]: The main point is that wildland fires play a crucial ecological role but have become more severe and frequent due to land use practices and climate change, posing significant risks to communities, especially in the Wildland Urban Interface (WUI).

[Why is it happening?]: The increase in severity and frequency of wildland fires is due to a century of land use practices like fire suppression, grazing, and timber harvesting, which have led to dense vegetation accumulations. Climate change, resulting in drier conditions and longer fire seasons, also contributes to the problem.

[Who is involved?]: Federal land management agencies, state and local governments, Indian tribes, nonfederal entities, and communities are involved in addressing wildland fire risks.

[When is the action happening?]: The actions are ongoing and have been intensifying over the past decades, with increased focus in recent years due to the growing threat to communities and the need for more effective wildland fire management strategies.

[Where is the action happening?]: The actions are happening across the United States, involving federal, state, local, private, and tribal lands, particularly in areas prone to wildland fires such as the WUI.

[What is the main point?]: The U.S. General Accounting Office (GAO) audited the Battle of Normandy Foundation's use of surcharge coin proceeds and found significant financial problems, including a deficit and weak internal controls, casting doubt on the Foundation's ability to continue operations and fulfill its commitments.

[Why is it happening?]: The GAO's audit was prompted by concerns about the Foundation's financial management, allegations of mismanagement, and the need to ensure the funds were used as intended for the Memorial Garden and other projects.

[Who is involved?]: The Battle of Normandy Foundation, the U.S. Treasury, the GAO, and various individuals and entities involved in the Foundation's operations, including its former president Anthony C. Stout and related party transactions.

[When is the action happening?]: The GAO's audit took place from September 1993 through August 1994, with the report issued in September 1994.

[Where is the action happening?]: The audit and subsequent events primarily took place in Washington, D.C., with the Memorial Garden located in the city of Caen, France.

[What is the main point?]: Pension plans are increasingly investing in hedge funds and private equity to diversify their portfolios and potentially achieve higher returns, but these investments pose significant challenges and require a high degree of fiduciary effort, expertise, and resources to manage effectively.

[Why is it happening?]: Pension plans are seeking to diversify their investment portfolios and obtain higher returns than traditional stock and bond investments, but have faced challenges due to the complexities and risks associated with hedge funds and private equity.

[Who is involved?]: Pension plan sponsors, fiduciaries, investment consultants, regulatory agencies, and investment advisory committees are involved in the management and oversight of pension plan investments in hedge funds and private equity.

[When is the action happening?]: The trend of pension plans investing in hedge funds and private equity has been ongoing, with recent years showing a continued increase in such investments.

[Where is the action happening?]: The actions are happening within the context of private and public pension plans, with varying regulations and oversight at the state and federal levels in the United States.

[What is the main point?]: The main point is that the territories of the United States, with the exception of Puerto Rico, have unique Medicaid and CHIP program structures and funding mechanisms, which result in varied program integrity efforts and challenges in ensuring program integrity due to limited resources and federal oversight.

[Why is it happening?]: It is happening due to the territories' small populations, relative poverty, and the flexibility granted to them in administering their Medicaid and CHIP programs, which differ from the states in terms of funding, eligibility standards, and administrative structures.

[Who is involved?]: The involved parties include the territories of American Samoa, CNMI, Guam, Puerto Rico, and the U.S. Virgin Islands, as well as the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS), the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS), and the Department of the Interior (DOI).

[When is the action happening?]: The action is ongoing, with recent legislation providing temporary increases in Medicaid and CHIP funding, and the permanent increase in Medicaid FMAPs and CHIP enhanced FMAPs to 55 percent and 68.5 percent, respectively, under the PPACA.

[Where is the action happening?]: The action is happening within the territories of the United States, specifically in American Samoa, CNMI, Guam, Puerto Rico, and the U.S. Virgin Islands.

[What is the main point?]: The main point is that the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and state officials are uncertain about the cleanup status and future actions for 1,789 potentially eligible hazardous waste sites awaiting a National Priorities List (NPL) decision, with concerns about risks to human health and the environment, cleanup actions taken, and responsible parties' participation.

[Why is it happening?]: The uncertainty stems from incomplete or missing information on the sites, the need for accurate risk assessments, and questions about responsible parties' willingness and ability to participate in cleanups.

[Who is involved?]: The EPA, state governments, and federal agencies responsible for managing potentially eligible sites are involved in addressing these sites.

[When is the action happening?]: The action is ongoing, with some sites having undergone cleanup activities, while others have not seen any progress or have no information available on cleanup activities.

[Where is the action happening?]: The actions are happening at potentially eligible sites located in 48 states, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and the Northern Mariana Islands, under the jurisdiction of the Navajo Nation.

[What is the main point?]: The main point is that the U.S. Department of State (State) needs to develop a long-term strategy to address the increasing worldwide demand for nonimmigrant visas (NIVs) and maintain a balance between national security and facilitating legitimate travel.

[Why is it happening?]: The demand for NIVs is increasing due to factors such as demographic, economic, political, and commercial changes in various countries. The Department of State has not yet developed a strategy to cope with this growth, which could lead to longer wait times for visa interviews and potentially discourage legitimate travelers.

[Who is involved?]: The U.S. Department of State, the Department of Commerce, and consular officers at U.S. embassies and consulates worldwide are involved in managing the visa process.

[When is the action happening?]: The Department of State has not yet developed a long-term strategy to address the increasing demand for NIVs.

[Where is the action happening?]: The actions are happening at U.S. embassies and consulates worldwide, particularly in countries with high visa demand such as Brazil, China, India, and Mexico.

[What is the main point?]: The main point is to assess the status of the Office of Personnel Management's (OPM) efforts toward planning and implementing the RetireEZ program and evaluate the effectiveness of the agency's management of the modernization initiative.

[Why is it happening?]: This assessment is happening due to concerns about OPM's ability to successfully implement the RetireEZ program, which aims to modernize and improve the federal retirement processing system.

[Who is involved?]: The Office of Personnel Management (OPM), the Office of Management and Budget (OMB), Hewitt Associates, Accenture Ltd., Northrop Grumman Corporation, and federal agencies are involved in the RetireEZ program.

[When is the action happening?]: The actions related to the RetireEZ program are ongoing, with the last update provided in March 2009.

[Where is the action happening?]: The actions are happening at OPM headquarters in Washington, D.C., the Retirement Operations Center in Boyers, Pennsylvania, and contractor facilities in Herndon, Virginia.

[What is the main point?] The main point is that the four bilingual education programs in the United States, while sharing similar goals and targeting the same population, are redundant and overlap significantly, leading to inefficiencies in serving students with limited English proficiency.

[Why is it happening?] The redundancy and overlap among the four bilingual education programs are occurring because they were designed to achieve the same overall objectives, but lack the necessary flexibility to cater to the varied needs of school districts serving students with limited English proficiency.

[Who is involved?] The main stakeholders involved are the U.S. Department of Education, school districts, and students with limited English proficiency.

[When is the action happening?] The action of consolidating the four bilingual education programs into one is being considered by the Congress and supported by the Department of Education.

[Where is the action happening?] The action is happening at the federal level, specifically within the U.S. Department of Education and Congress, as they deliberate on the reauthorization of the Bilingual Education Act (BEA) and consider the consolidation of the four bilingual education programs.

[What is the main point?]: The main point is that the National Crime Information Center (NCIC) system, managed by the FBI, requires law enforcement agencies to enter reports of missing children into its database within 2 hours, but compliance varies, and there are challenges in meeting this requirement.

[Why is it happening?]: The challenges in meeting the 2-hour entry requirement for missing children reports are due to custody disputes, coordination with child welfare agencies, and other factors that delay reporting or investigation.

[Who is involved?]: The FBI, state and local law enforcement agencies, the Criminal Justice Information Services (CJIS), the Criminal Justice Information and Infrastructure (CJIS) Advisory Policy Board, the Office of Justice Programs (OJJDP), the National Center for Missing & Exploited Children (NCMEC), and the Child Welfare League of America are involved in addressing the challenges and ensuring compliance with the 2-hour entry requirement.

[When is the action happening?]: The action is ongoing, with the FBI and CJIS conducting triennial audits of state agencies (CSAs) to assess compliance with NCIC policies, including the 2-hour entry requirement.

[Where is the action happening?]: The action is happening nationwide, as the NCIC system serves as a repository of data for law enforcement agencies across the United States.

[What is the main point?]: The main point is to examine the independent effects of various factors on the risk of injury in automobile crashes, focusing on crash type, crash severity, automobile size, safety belt use, and occupant age and gender.

[Why is it happening?]: This examination is happening to isolate the factors that contribute to occupant injury in collisions and to understand how to improve automobile safety for different driver demographics and crash scenarios.

[Who is involved?]: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA), the Department of Transportation (DOT), auto safety experts, and representatives of automobile manufacturers are involved in this examination.

[When is the action happening?]: The action is happening over the course of several years, with the report looking at data from 1988 to 1991 and considering safety initiatives from NHTSA that have been implemented from 1990 onwards.

[Where is the action happening?]: The action is happening in the United States, where automobiles are associated with a significant number of traffic fatalities annually.

[What is the main point?]: The U.S. Coast Guard is a multimission maritime service within the Department of Homeland Security, responsible for executing missions across the Pacific and Atlantic areas, with over 46,000 full-time positions and 31,000 volunteer auxiliary personnel. It has two broad missions, homeland security and non-homeland security, divided into 11 programs with performance measures to assess effectiveness and inform budgeting.

[Why is it happening?]: The Coast Guard is undergoing reorganization to improve command and control structures, streamline operations, and address acquisition challenges, particularly in the Deepwater program.

[Who is involved?]: The U.S. Coast Guard, Department of Homeland Security, Congress, and various Coast Guard officials and personnel are involved in the reorganization and management of the Coast Guard's missions and assets.

[When is the action happening?]: The Coast Guard's reorganization efforts and budget initiatives are ongoing, with the fiscal year 2008 budget reflecting these changes.

[Where is the action happening?]: The actions are happening within the Coast Guard's operational structure, including its Pacific and Atlantic commands, sectors, and field units, as well as in the development and implementation of various acquisition programs and performance measures.

[What is the main point?]: The main point is that the Department of Defense (DOD) has not developed a comprehensive plan to effectively implement the Families First program, which aims to improve the quality of service for servicemembers during household goods moves, and this lack of planning is putting the program at risk.

[Why is it happening?]: The DOD has faced numerous management challenges and delays in implementing the Families First program, which has been ongoing for over 11 years with little progress. The program's goals include improving service quality, streamlining claims processing, and developing a new information management system (DPS). However, the DOD has encountered issues with staffing, stakeholder agreement, and funding, which have hindered its progress.

[Who is involved?]: The U.S. Transportation Command, the Surface Deployment and Distribution Command, the Joint Program Management Office for Household Goods Systems, the Military Surface Deployment and Distribution Command, the U.S. Transportation Command's Program Executive Office for Distribution Services, the Army, Navy, Air Force, Marine Corps, Coast Guard, moving industry associations, and DOD officials are involved in the Families First program.

[When is the action happening?]: The action is ongoing, with the DOD continuing to work on the Families First program and its associated system. The U.S. Transportation Command plans to provide funding for DPS development, testing, fielding, and maintenance, and the DOD is expected to provide a comprehensive plan for Families First implementation in August 2007.

[Where is the action happening?]: The action is happening at various locations, including the Washington, D.C. area, Scott Air Force Base in Illinois, and the U.S. Transportation Command's Program Executive Office for Distribution U.S. Transportation Command's Strategy, Policy, Programs and Logistics U.S. Transportation Command's Program Analysis and Financial Management Directorate.

[What is the main point?]: The main point of the document is to discuss the use of pesticides on tobacco crops, the potential health risks associated with these pesticides, and the regulatory measures in place to manage these risks.

[Why is it happening?]: Pesticides are used on tobacco crops to increase production and reduce crop-destroying pests. However, exposure to pesticides can harm humans, and the potential for harm depends on the dose, toxicity of the chemical, and the individual's age and health status.

[Who is involved?]: The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA), and other federal agencies are involved in regulating and monitoring pesticide residues on tobacco.

[When is the action happening?]: The document discusses actions taken by these agencies from the 1990s to the early 2000s, including the review and reregistration of pesticides, the establishment of residue limits, and the testing of imported and domestic tobacco for pesticide residues.

[Where is the action happening?]: The actions are happening in the United States, where tobacco is grown and imported, and in countries like Germany, Italy, and Spain that import U.S. tobacco and have set their own residue limits.

[What is the main point?]: The main point of the document is to provide a comprehensive guide on the design and implementation of user fees for federal programs, considering factors such as equity, efficiency, revenue adequacy, and administrative burden.

[Why is it happening?]: The guide is being created to assist policymakers in designing user fees that are fair, cover program costs, and align with the expectations of payers who receive specific government services or benefits.

[Who is involved?]: The Office of Management and Budget (OMB), the Secretaries of Homeland Security, Defense, and Agriculture, and various government agencies are involved in the creation and review of the guide.

[When is the action happening?]: The guide was drafted and reviewed by the OMB and the mentioned government officials, with technical comments incorporated from the agencies.

[Where is the action happening?]: The actions related to the guide are taking place within the federal government, specifically in the offices of the OMB and the mentioned government departments. The guide is also available on the GAO website for public access.

[What is the main point?]: The main point is that the District of Columbia's Office of the State Superintendent of Education (OSSE) and the District of Columbia Public Schools (DCPS) have not consistently followed policies and procedures for monitoring the use of federal payments for school improvement, leading to potential misuse of funds and lack of accountability for meeting performance outcomes.

[Why is it happening?]: This is happening due to weaknesses in internal controls related to information management across administrations, as well as inadequate monitoring practices for grants and contracts.

[Who is involved?]: The Mayor of the District of Columbia, OSSE, DCPS, the D.C. Office of the Chief Financial Officer, the D.C. Public Charter School Board, and various program offices within DCPS are involved in managing and monitoring the use of federal payments.

[When is the action happening?]: The action of monitoring federal payments and improving internal controls is ongoing, with the report being conducted from October 2009 to November 2010.

[Where is the action happening?]: The action is happening within the District of Columbia's school system, specifically at OSSE and DCPS, as well as at the contracting offices responsible for managing contracts funded through federal payments.

[What is the main point?]: The U.S. government's current fiscal condition necessitates strategic choices between unlimited wants and affordable, sustainable needs, requiring a fundamental re-examination of federal contracting approaches.

[Why is it happening?]: The need arises due to the government's long-term fiscal outlook and the requirement to seek the best return on investments in goods and services within fiscal constraints.

[Who is involved?]: The federal government, including various agencies like DOD, DOE, DHS, and others, as well as Congress, contractors, and the private sector.

[When is the action happening?]: The actions are ongoing and have been reported on multiple occasions, with the latest reports in 2007.

[Where is the action happening?]: The actions are happening within the federal government, across various agencies, and in the context of federal contracting and acquisition processes.

[What is the main point?] The main point is that the Department of Defense (DOD) has faced challenges in setting a standard fuel price that closely approximates its actual fuel costs, and in recent years its estimated fuel prices have differed significantly from actual costs due to changes in fuel market conditions not being reflected in the standard price.

[Why is it happening?] It is happening because DOD's current approach for estimating the components of the standard price has not accounted for changes in market conditions for crude oil, such as the decreasing relationship between crude oil and refined prices, and has not documented its rationale for continuing to use the same assumptions.

[Who is involved?] The Office of the Under Secretary of Defense (Comptroller), the Defense Logistics Agency (DLA), the military services, the Department of Energy’s Energy Information Administration, and the Office of Management and Budget are involved in this issue.

[When is the action happening?] The action of reevaluating DOD's approach for estimating the components of the standard price and documenting its assumptions is recommended to be directed by the Secretary of Defense.

[Where is the action happening?] The action is happening within the Department of Defense, specifically in coordination with the Office of the Under Secretary of Defense (Comptroller) and the Defense Logistics Agency (DLA).

[What is the main point?] The main point is that the Department of Defense (DOD) has not effectively managed the Standard Procurement System (SPS) program, failing to meet key commitments and justify further investment in the system.

[Why is it happening?] The lack of proper investment management processes, unclear accountability, and insufficient validation of economic benefits have led to this situation.

[Who is involved?] The DOD, including various agencies and military services, the Assistant Secretary of Defense for Command, Control, Communications, and Intelligence (C3I), the Office of the Director of Defense Procurement, and the Office of the Under Secretary of Defense for Acquisition, Technology and Logistics are involved.

[When is the action happening?] The action is ongoing, with the report highlighting issues from October 2000 to June 2001.

[Where is the action happening?] The action is happening at DOD headquarters offices in Washington, D.C., and Alexandria, Virginia, as well as at American Management Systems, Incorporated, headquarters in Fairfax, Virginia.

[What is the main point?]: USCIS is responsible for processing immigration benefit applications, detecting fraud, and referring suspicious cases for investigation.
[Why is it happening?]: To ensure the integrity of the immigration system and to protect against fraud.
[Who is involved?]: USCIS, FDNS, ICE, DHS, State Department, DOL, and U.S. Attorneys Office.
[When is the action happening?]: The actions are ongoing, with USCIS continuously processing applications and conducting fraud assessments.
[Where is the action happening?]: The actions are taking place at USCIS service centers, district offices, and in coordination with ICE and other federal agencies.

[What is the main point?] The main point is to assess the IRS' performance during the 1994 filing season, focusing on processing accuracy and efficiency, and providing taxpayers with access to forms, information, and electronic filing methods.
[Why is it happening?] The assessment is happening due to the need to ensure the IRS is effectively managing various programs and addressing issues such as increased fraudulent refund claims and difficulties taxpayers face in reaching IRS over the phone.
[Who is involved?] The Internal Revenue Service (IRS), the U.S. General Accounting Office (GAO), IRS officials, taxpayers, and other interested parties are involved in this assessment.
[When is the action happening?] The assessment took place from January through August 1994, with a final exit conference held on September 26, 1994.
[Where is the action happening?] The action is happening within the IRS, at its service centers, and through various IRS-related systems and processes, including the National Office Command Center and the toll-free telephone assistance system.

[What is the main point?]: The main point is that Tennessee's Medicaid demonstration project, TennCare, aims to control costs and expand healthcare coverage through a capitated managed care system, but faces challenges in maintaining provider participation and ensuring quality and access to care due to financial difficulties and concerns about capitation rates.

[Why is it happening?]: TennCare is facing financial challenges for MCOs, leading to potential cuts in provider payments and pressure on providers to reduce costs. Additionally, there are concerns about the adequacy of capitation rates and the impact on quality and access to care.

[Who is involved?]: The main parties involved are the state of Tennessee, the Health Care Financing Administration (HCFA), Medicaid Managed Care Organizations (MCOs), healthcare providers, and beneficiaries.

[When is the action happening?]: The action is ongoing, with the TennCare demonstration project having been in effect since January 1, 1994, and the review and analysis of its implementation and impact continuing up to the time of the report's writing in May 1995.

[Where is the action happening?]: The action is happening in Tennessee, with specific reference to the state's healthcare system and the operations of the TennCare program.

[What is the main point?]: The main point is that while federal entities now have improved tools to detect drug use, there are still concerns about the efficiency and effectiveness of these efforts, and a lack of a defined strategy for responding to emerging drug use trends.

[Why is it happening?]: This situation is happening due to the complexities of addressing drug use problems, which involve multiple factors such as data uncertainties, resource limitations, and the need for collaborative response actions among federal, state, and local entities.

[Who is involved?]: The federal entities involved include the Office of National Drug Control Policy (ONDCP), the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA), the National Institute on Drug Abuse (NIDA), and state and local substance abuse authorities.

[When is the action happening?]: The actions are ongoing, with efforts to address emerging drug problems continuously being implemented by these agencies.

[Where is the action happening?]: The actions are happening at the national level, involving federal agencies and state and local communities, although there is a recognized need for stronger linkages and coordination at the local level.

[What is the main point?]: The main point is that the worker-profiling initiative, which identifies unemployment claimants likely to exhaust benefits and refers them to reemployment services, is not being effectively implemented or evaluated, leading to potential misallocation of resources.

[Why is it happening?]: The worker-profiling initiative was implemented to target reemployment services to those most likely to benefit, but many states have not updated their profiling models for years, risking the loss of predictive accuracy and effectiveness.

[Who is involved?]: The U.S. Department of Labor (DOL), state unemployment agencies, and various experts and officials from states and the Upjohn Institute for Employment Research are involved in the implementation and evaluation of the worker-profiling initiative.

[When is the action happening?]: The action of profiling and referring claimants to reemployment services has been ongoing since the enactment of the Unemployment Compensation Amendments in 1993, with periodic reporting to Congress and guidance issued by the DOL.

[Where is the action happening?]: The action is happening at the state level, with each state utilizing its own profiling models and reemployment services to identify and assist unemployment claimants.

[What is the main point?] The main point is that the Medicare subvention demonstration, which allowed older military retirees to receive Medicare benefits and additional TRICARE benefits, resulted in higher costs for the Department of Defense (DOD) due to increased utilization of services by Senior Prime enrollees, who were healthier and used more services than comparable Medicare beneficiaries.

[Why is it happening?] The demonstration was implemented to provide greater access to health care for older military retirees and to see if managed care could be a cost-effective alternative to traditional Medicare. However, the higher utilization of services by Senior Prime enrollees, who were less costly to care for, led to increased costs for DOD.

[Who is involved?] The Department of Defense (DOD), the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS), Medicare beneficiaries, and the military retirees who were eligible for the Medicare subvention demonstration.

[When is the action happening?] The Medicare subvention demonstration took place from January 1, 1998, to December 31, 2000, with an extension through 2001 due to the Floyd D. Spence National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2001.

[Where is the action happening?] The actions are happening within the United States, specifically at military treatment facilities (MTFs), civilian health care providers, and through the Medicare national mail order pharmacy (NMOP) and civilian pharmacies.

[What is the main point?] The main point is that the National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) has made significant progress in implementing leading management practices and addressing human capital and training center issues, but there are still areas that require improvement.

[Why is it happening?] The NTSB is implementing these changes to improve its efficiency, address diversity in its workforce, and better utilize its resources for transportation safety.

[Who is involved?] The NTSB, the Government Accountability Office (GAO), and various federal agencies are involved in this process.

[When is the action happening?] The actions are ongoing, with progress reported since April 2008 and continued efforts initiated since then.

[Where is the action happening?] The actions are taking place within the NTSB and its various departments, as well as in collaboration with other federal agencies and the Training Center.

[What is the main point?] The main point is to evaluate the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) progress in addressing its major management challenges, particularly in strategic human capital management and information security, as identified by the GAO and EPA's OIG.

[Why is it happening?] This evaluation is happening due to concerns raised about the EPA's performance and management challenges, and the need for the agency to improve its performance in these areas.

[Who is involved?] The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), the Government Accountability Office (GAO), and the Office of Inspector General (OIG) are involved in this evaluation.

[When is the action happening?] The action is happening from April 2001 through June 2001.

[Where is the action happening?] The action is taking place within the EPA's operations and programs, specifically in relation to the agency's fiscal year 2000 performance report and the fiscal year 2002 performance plan.

[What is the main point?]: The main point is that the Department of Defense (DOD) is seeking ways to improve operations and manage resources more efficiently through the Corporate Information Management (CIM) initiative, which aims to streamline business processes and eliminate redundant information systems across various functional areas.

[Why is it happening?]: The DOD is facing budget constraints and needs to find ways to save money and improve efficiency. The CIM initiative was launched in response to the recommendations of the President's Blue Ribbon Commission on Defense Management and the Defense Management Report, which estimated that DOD could save about $70 billion by improving its management and organization.

[Who is involved?]: The main parties involved are the Department of Defense (DOD), the Executive Level Group of high-level industry and DOD officials, the Deputy Secretary of Defense, the Assistant Secretary of Defense for Command, Control, Communication, and Intelligence (C3I), Principal Staff Assistants (PSAs), the Joint Logistics System Center (JLSC), the Department of Defense Comptroller, and various service and Defense Logistics Agency (DLA) managers.

[When is the action happening?]: The CIM initiative started in 1989 and has been ongoing, with various milestones and shifts in focus over the years. The most recent developments mentioned in the document occurred between October 1992 and July 1994.

[Where is the action happening?]: The actions are taking place at the Office of the Assistant Secretary of Defense for C3I in Washington, D.C., the Office of the Assistant Secretary of Defense for Production and Logistics in Alexandria, Virginia, and the Joint Logistics Systems Center in Wright-Patterson Air Force Base, Ohio.

[What is the main point?]: The main point is that the investigation involved producing counterfeit NRC documents and radioactive sources to test the effectiveness of border security measures and the potential for creating a dirty bomb.

[Why is it happening?]: The investigation aimed to assess the vulnerabilities in the system for transporting radioactive materials across borders and to highlight the issues with counterfeit NRC documents.

[Who is involved?]: The investigation was conducted by a team of investigators, including a GAO graphic artist, and involved the Customs and Border Protection (CBP) and the Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC).

[When is the action happening?]: The undercover operation took place on December 14, 2005, and a follow-up briefing with CBP and NRC officials occurred on December 21, 2005, and January 12 and 22, 2006.

[Where is the action happening?]: The actions were carried out at official ports of entry between Canada and the United States, and at the southern border.

[What is the main point?]: The main point is that the Department of Defense (DOD) is increasing its investment in technology transition programs to overcome challenges in integrating new technologies from research labs into military operations, but these programs face issues such as inadequate demonstration of potential, unwillingness to fund final development stages, and budgeting constraints.

[Why is it happening?]: It is happening because DOD recognizes the need to more effectively transition promising technologies from the lab to actual use to maintain technological superiority and improve military operations.

[Who is involved?]: The Department of Defense, Congress, industry, academia, and various DOD research and acquisition programs are involved in the development and transition of new technologies.

[When is the action happening?]: The action is ongoing, with DOD increasing its investment in technology transition programs and Congress establishing initiatives like the Technology Transition Initiative (TTI), the Defense Acquisition Challenge Program (DACP), and the Quick Reaction Fund (QRF) since fiscal year 2003.

[Where is the action happening?]: The action is happening within DOD's research and development labs, test facilities, and acquisition programs, as well as in partnerships with industry and academia.

[What is the main point?]: The main point is that the U.S. Census Bureau's schedules for MAF development programs are not fully reliable, with issues in comprehensiveness, construction, and credibility.
[Why is it happening?]: The Bureau's schedules lack comprehensiveness, proper sequencing, and a critical path, and do not include a quantitative risk analysis, making it difficult for management to assess progress and make informed decisions.
[Who is involved?]: The U.S. Census Bureau, specifically the Geography Division and the 2020 Research and Planning Office, are involved in MAF development and scheduling.
[When is the action happening?]: The Bureau is in the process of developing and testing targeted address canvassing proposals, with a focus on improving the MAF for the 2020 Census.
[Where is the action happening?]: The actions are taking place within the Bureau's internal operations, focusing on MAF development and scheduling for the 2020 Census.

[What is the main point?]: The main point of the document is to assess the extent to which the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has completed the various actions required to meet the objectives of Titles I, III, and IV of the Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990, which address national ambient air quality standards, hazardous air pollutants, and acid deposition control.

[Why is it happening?]: The assessment is happening because the Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990 mandated numerous actions to reduce air pollution, and it is important to evaluate the progress and effectiveness of these actions in improving air quality.

[Who is involved?]: The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) is involved in implementing the requirements of the Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990.

[When is the action happening?]: The assessment was conducted from January 2005 to May 2005.

[Where is the action happening?]: The action is happening within the United States, as the Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990 are a federal law that applies nationwide.
